No other structure we have created can do
this as well as the Community Action Agency.
Electronic mass communications media, radio
and television, because they are a part of
today's life-experience, must be exploited,
shaped into a working tool which can deliver
those program components dynamically. Few other
experiences are as meaningful as face-to-face
confrontation, television makes that possible.
We are not talking about "enrichment". We are
describing a day-to-day "learning experience"
being delivered more forcefully, and in greater
depth, than has hitherto been possible through
more conventional distribution means. And we
are talking, realistically, about reaching a
greater portion of the poverty population and
getting them involved in those processes of
individual and social reconstruction.
